data.title: Atom had unexpectedly crashed when I didn't want it to.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom crashed when I didn't save my work.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Find my work at [**@amayarora**](https://github.com/amayarora).
2. Go to files GitHub > pkb > Academics > School > Intermediate > Grade V > History > Chapter XII.md.
3. Recover Section II: *Who Were the Loyalists and Patriots?*, along with part of Section III: *Loyalists and Patriots*. Atom had crashed during this time, and didn't save my work. You should be able to find this work in one of the previous commits, which I really didn't commit, since it didn't save, but hopefully you know what I mean.

**Expected behavior:** Have my work to be saved!

**Actual behavior:** It did not save! GAHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

**Reproduces how often:** Once, please.

### Versions

Input: `atom --version`
Output: 
```
Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

### Additional Information

Nothing, just help me bro!

data.title: Added prevent option to ::onWillDestroyPaneItem()
data.body:
### Description of the Change

This PR implements the feature requested in issue #12376. It adds a method to the parameter of the `::onWillDestroyPaneItem` callback named `prevent` which allows packages to prevent a tab from closing by adding an event listener via `::onWillDestroyPaneItem`

### Alternate Designs

An alternative for the requested feature overall isn't really present, as the previous implementation would close the tab no matter what or request the user to safe in case of unsaved changes. Both of these are unwanted behaviour as described in #12376.

As for alternative ways to implement the functionality, I considered `prevent` to be a (boolean) value instead of a function. However, this seemed not such a good choice mainly because I find it more intuitive to use as a function, but also because JavaScript can't enforce the value to be a boolean.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

As explained in #12376, the problem is that it isn't part of the core. As of now it is nearly impossible to implement this as a package, and non of the solutions I could think of are even remotely elegant (e.g. recording what tab(s) closed and reopening them after they've been closed).

### Benefits

It will help developers of packages prevent the unwanted closing of "special" tabs e.g. when "Close all tabs" is called by the user. This has, for example, been requested in [this](https://github.com/ericcornelissen/pinned-tabs-for-atom/issues/20) issue on one of my own packages.

### Possible Drawbacks

When used incorrectly this functionality could make closing tabs impossible for users. However, simply disabling the package that uses this functionality incorrectly will solve the problem.

### Applicable Issues

N/A

data.title: Atom crashes on Linux: [26686:0214/075533:INFO:CONSOLE(61)] "Error: Could not create an input method.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On executing atom 1.14.1 on Arch Linux (from official repo), there is a crash reporting: `"Error: Could not create an input method"`.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Execute atom (UI or CLI)

**Expected behavior:** Atom will run

**Actual behavior:** It crashes:
![screenshot_2017-02-14_07-56-55](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/73091/22917175/e0b0786c-f28b-11e6-8ce5-3e2f8f49435d.png)
![screenshot_2017-02-14_07-56-16](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/73091/22917176/e0b3e858-f28b-11e6-9be7-a0393c19fb6b.png)


**Reproduces how often:** It constantly happens. even after removing all of the directories of atom -> $HOME/.atom and $HOME/.config/Atom

### Versions
I'm using Atom 1.14.1 on Arch Linux 64 bit from the official repository of Arch Linux:
- Atom    : 1.14.1
- Electron: 1.4.15
- Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
- Node    : 6.5.0

- apm  1.15.2
- npm  4.2.0
- node 7.5.0 x64
- python 3.6.0
- git 2.11.1

- Linux - 4.9.8-1-ARCH

data.title: Fix code-signing on CircleCI
data.body:
We're seeing the following error message in [this failing build](https://circleci.com/gh/atom/atom/2588) on CircleCI:

```
SecKey API returned: -25293, (null)/Users/distiller/atom/out/Atom.app: unknown error -1=ffffffffffffffff
```

Based on [this Stack Overflow article](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/39868578/security-codesign-in-sierra-keychain-ignores-access-control-settings-and-ui-p) it looks like they *may* have upgraded their images to Sierra and are causing this problem.

This PR runs the ✨  command suggested in that article to hopefully fix the issue.

data.title: Overhaul element pool and debug double-free errors
data.body:
In researching the cause of https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13377, we've decided to make some changes to the element pool.

1) Based on a hypothesis that a package could be inserting foreign nodes into the text editor's DOM structure, we now only free elements that the element pool itself created.
2) If the above hypothesis is incorrect, we now report *assertion failures* rather than throwing exceptions, and include the HTML of the freed element just in case that might be helpful.

In addition, we've converted the class and tests to JS and removed some closure allocations on :fire: code paths.

We think we should probably merge this only to 1.15 (beta) because it's a somewhat risky change, but we'd like to get feedback pretty soon from it.

/cc @maxbrunsfeld

I'm newer with atom, but i not found anything about this (probably I don't know how find it), The thing is,

I understand that atom ignore "node_modules" because we don't need read all files into that librearies, but in this case is not the same.

Thanks.

data.title: Eliminate TextEditorComponent's reliance on MutationObserver for detecting changes in visibility, dimensions, and background color
data.body:
With the introduction of Chrome 53 in Electron 1.4, we now have access to a fully functional `IntersectionObserver` API, which can be used to detect when editors change in visibility. This means we can discard the previous `MutationObserver` based polling system, which creates a drag on frame rates in certain circumstances. This impact is hard to quantify because *measuring* the frame rate with mutation observers in place in the current scrolling scheme seems to slow performance dramatically, making this hard to measure. Regardless it's a big simplification to not require full DOM observation.

This PR replaces polling with the following approaches:

* Visibility detection: [`IntersectionObserver`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Intersection_Observer_API)
* Resize detection of editors and overlay decorations: Scroll event hack via the [`element-resize-detector`](https://github.com/wnr/element-resize-detector) library.
* Transferring background to editor tiles: Plain CSS with `background-color: inherit` (now possible with the removal of the shadow DOM)

data.title: Editor stops respond when open a file with very long lines
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Editor stops respond when open a file with very long lines.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `curl -O https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.3.7/js/bootstrap.min.js`
2. `atom --safe bootstrap.min.js`
3. atom opens

**Expected behavior:** 

* Atom show all contents of bootstrap.min.js
* Atom response user input like mouse and keyboards.

**Actual behavior:** 

* Atom show partial contents of bootstrap.min.js
* Atom does not response any user input and show the follow dialog:

![screen shot 2017-02-11 at 6 36 58 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20248/22853166/e20a96b0-f089-11e6-9b63-976ac7354fa7.png)

**Reproduces how often:** 100% with or without Soft Wrap turns on.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.14.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.10.1

data.title: Installation requirements addition / Compilation on Raspberry Pi 3 / Raspbian Jessie
data.body:
Hello,

Im currently trying to compile Atom on an Raspberry / arm architecture.

Its working fine, using the installation instruction, just one more thing:
I noticed there is one more requirement to be added which was not installed previously -
libxkb*** - which does the include "X11/extensions/xkbrules.h"

Its inside keyboard-layout-manager.cc @ 5:37

Perhaps this should become added to the note of requirements.

If I encounter any other problem, I report it here. But for now, all seems to be compiling smoothly.

Kind regards on behalf of an arm user.

data.title: macOS: Custom Title Bar makes native tabs look ugly
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When the "Use Custom Title Bar" option is enabled on macOS, the system tabs look ugly - they seem to be transparent and overlap with the window's contents (ie. Atom's tabs).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start Atom with "Use Custom Title Bar" option enabled (*Preferences -> Core -> Use Custom Title Bar*)
2. Show macOS native tabs if not already visible (View -> Show Tab Bar)
3. Despair

**Expected behavior:** The native tab bar should not overlap with the window's contents and should probably not be transparent. Ideally, the tab bar would match the title bar's colour.

**Actual behavior:** The tab bar is displayed **over** the window's contents and seems to be transparent

**Reproduces how often:** 100%, with any theme selected

### Versions

Atom 1.14
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.1

### Additional Information

An obligatory screenshot:

![macos - broken native tab bar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3058150/22838121/ed589344-efc3-11e6-87d5-5212a2915ffe.png)

data.title: apm outdated returning undefined when seti-syntax is installed
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [ x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description apm outdated returns undefined ### Steps to Reproduce 1. run "apm outdated" on the commandline 2. returns undefined 3. run "apm list" 4. shows what appears to be a proper list of packages **Expected behavior:** return JSON of outdated packages **Actual behavior:** returns undefined **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions $ atom --version; apm --version Atom : 1.14.1 Electron: 1.3.13 Chrome : 52.0.2743.82 Node : 6.5.0 apm 1.15.3 npm 3.10.5 node 4.4.5 x64 python 2.7.10 git 2.2.1 ### Additional Information noticed that the Updates in Settings were failing and tracked it to the apm call

data.title: enhancement : msi installer should install system wide and not a system wide installer
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

A MSI installer as been created for Atom. But it's not an installer for Atom. It's an installer for the Installer ! After installation, you don't have Atom in c:\Programs but an Installer of Atom and atom.exe still lives in personnal directory

### Steps to Reproduce

install with msiexec 

**Expected behavior:** 

having atom.exe living in c:\Programs\atom\

**Actual behavior:** 

An atom installer lives in C:\Programs and atom.exe lives in user personnal directory. Why is it so crucial for us ?  We are a high shcool and we teach code to our students. We have 1200 students and are low on budget for server storage space. 

Every student has an allocation of approximately 300M for personnal space, and another 200M for sharing space. That's all we can do.

And... atom installation is more than 300M in size ! It's useless because those 300M could perfectly be stored in C:\Program\atom\ and shared for all the users of the computer.

**Reproduces how often:** 

100%

### Versions

1.14.1 on windows 7 64bits

### Additional Information

I've made some test so far, with copying brutally the content of a personnal atom setup in the system Programs directory, it seems to work for non priviledged users. The program files should live in system, and only customization should live in personnal data

data.title: Linux 32bit Source Build Fails Installation
data.body:
I've just built 1.14.0 & 1.15.0-beta0 32bit Linux DEBs, RPMs and GZs on Fedora 25. Builds were all successful.

Trying to install both fails with the foloowing messages:

rpm -Uvh /strg/ftp/ibnd/Atom-LnxX32-1.15.0b0.rpm
error: Failed dependencies:
	libXss.so.1()(64bit) is needed by atom-beta-1.15.0.beta0-0.1.fc25.i686

rpm -Uvh /strg/ftp/ibnd/Atom-LnxX32-1.14.0.rpm
error: Failed dependencies:
	libXss.so.1()(64bit) is needed by atom-1.14.0-0.1.fc25.i686
